title: A Unified Electron Scale Relation from Classical Radius, Compton Frequency, and the Hydrogen Ground State Energy
description:
This manuscript derives and analyzes an exact algebraic identity linking three standard electron scales that usually appear in separate parts of the physics curriculum: the classical electron radius \(r_e\), the Compton angular frequency \(\omega_C\), and the hydrogen ground-state energy \(E_B\). Using only textbook definitions and CODATA values of \(m_e\), \(\alpha\), \(\hbar\), and \(c\), the author constructs a purely classical Hooke-law oscillator with electron mass \(m_e\), frequency \(\omega_\ast = \omega_C/\alpha\), and amplitude equal to the classical radius \(r_e\). This oscillator defines a maximal restoring force
\[
F_{\max} = m_e\left(\frac{\omega_C}{\alpha}\right)^2 r_e,
\]
which can be written entirely in terms of fundamental constants. The central result is that there exists a Compton-scale radius \(r_c\) such that
\[
F_{\max} r_c = \frac{1}{2} m_e c^2 = \frac{E_B}{\alpha^2},
\]
so that the half electron rest energy and the Bohr ground-state energy (rescaled by \(\alpha^{-2}\)) emerge from a single, dimensionally consistent construction involving \(r_e\) and \(\omega_C\). The paper carefully states all standard definitions (fine-structure constant, classical electron radius, Compton wavelength/frequency, Bohr energy), performs explicit dimensional checks, and evaluates the identity numerically using CODATA 2014 constants. A short historical discussion recalls the independent origins of these scales in classical electron models (Lorentz–Abraham), Compton scattering, and Bohr/Schrödinger hydrogen theory. No new physical model or modification of quantum electrodynamics is proposed; the work is presented explicitly as a compact consistency relation among well-established electron scales, intended to clarify structural interdependencies between classical electrodynamics, relativistic kinematics, and atomic physics.
